docs.title: Komandorr
docs.text: Modern Service Monitoring Dashboard

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: Komandorr is a modern, feature-rich service monitoring dashboard designed to keep track of your applications, websites, panels, and projects. With built-in Plex integration, traffic monitoring, and a beautiful multi-theme interface, Komandorr makes monitoring your infrastructure simple and elegant.

docs.title: Service Monitoring
docs.text:
• Real-time Health Checks: Monitor HTTP/HTTPS endpoints with customizable intervals
  • Service Groups: Organize services into logical groups
  • Visual Status: Color-coded service cards with instant status visibility
  • Service Types: Support for websites, apps, panels, and servers

docs.title: VOD Streams (Plex Integration)
docs.text:
• Real-time Activity Monitoring: Track Plex downloads, streams, and transcodes
  • Progress Tracking: Visual progress bars for active operations
  • Search & Filter: Quickly find specific activities
  • Auto-refresh: Live updates every 10 seconds

docs.title: Traffic Monitoring
docs.text:
• Bandwidth Tracking: Monitor upload/download speeds per service
  • Real-time Data: Auto-refresh traffic statistics
  • Dashboard Integration: Traffic data displayed directly on service cards
  • Remote Agent: Monitor traffic from remote servers

docs.title: Themes & Customization
docs.text:
• Multiple Themes: Dark, Plex, Jellyfin, Emby, and more
  • Theme Switching: Instant theme changes with smooth transitions
  • Custom Branding: Komandorr orange accent color throughout

docs.title: Multi-Language Support
docs.text:
• English & German: Full bilingual support
  • Easy Switching: Change language on-the-fly
  • Complete Translation: All UI elements translated

docs.title: Security
docs.text:
• Optional Authentication: Basic HTTP authentication
  • Token-based: Secure API access
  • Configurable: Enable/disable as needed

docs.title: Quick Start
docs.text:
Get Komandorr up and running in minutes:

# Using Docker Compose
git clone https://github.com/cyb3rgh05t/komandorr.git
cd komandorr
docker-compose up -d

Visit http://localhost:3000 and start monitoring!

Installation Guide Configuration

docs.title: Features
docs.text:

  • Multi-Language: English and German translations
  • RESTful API: Complete API for automation and integration
  • Docker Support: Easy deployment with Docker and Docker Compose

docs.title: Changelog
docs.text:
All notable changes to Komandorr are documented here.

This file mirrors the main CHANGELOG.md from the repository.

docs.title: Dashboard: Comprehensive UI/UX Improvements
docs.text:
• Created dedicated DashboardServiceCard component for dashboard-specific service display
  • Added horizontal stats bar layout with individual stat boxes (Response Time, Last Check, Upload/Download Speed)
  • Removed Service ID display from dashboard cards for cleaner appearance
  • Integrated real-time traffic data directly into dashboard service cards
  • Stats now display with proper labels above values for consistent card sizing
  • Added conditional rendering for traffic data (only shows when available)

docs.title: Services: Enhanced Service Card Design
docs.text:
• Redesigned ServiceCard component with modern badge-based layout
  • Added Service ID display with copy-to-clipboard functionality
  • Conditional icon display (only renders if service has custom icon)
  • Improved action button layout with primary "Check Now" button
  • Consistent badge styling across all service information

docs.title: About: Improved Release Section
docs.text:
• Limited release display to 5 most recent releases for better performance
  • Added "View All Releases" button in section header (right-aligned)
  • Button only appears when more than 5 releases are available
  • Direct link to GitHub releases page for full release history
  • Added translations for "View All Releases" (English/German)

docs.title: About: Enhanced Documentation Access
docs.text:
• Added direct link to documentation site
  • Separated "Documentation" and "API Documentation" links for clarity
  • Both links open in new tabs with proper external link icons

docs.title: UI: Improved Consistency and Polish
docs.text:
• Added skeleton loading animations across all pages (Dashboard, Monitor, Traffic, Services)
  • Standardized content width across all pages (removed inconsistent max-width constraints)
  • All icons now use solid colors (removed opacity/fade effects)
  • Consistent badge styling throughout application
  • Progress bars now use solid theme colors

docs.title: VOD Streams: Comprehensive Timestamp Tracking System
docs.text:
• Implemented localStorage-based activity timestamp tracking with persistence
  • Added live timer badges showing elapsed time for active downloads
  • Smart tracking logic: starts immediately for new activities (<2%), waits for 1% progress change for in-progress activities
  • Timer states: undefined (new) → null (waiting) → number (tracking with timestamp)
  • Fixed timer reset issues on page refresh with proper state management
  • Added "Tracking..." state for activities waiting to start timing
  • Real-time timer updates with live elapsed time display

docs.title: Bug Fixes
docs.text:
• Dashboard: Fixed missing Search icon import after cleanup
  • Dashboard: Resolved ReferenceError when rendering search bar

docs.title: Documentation
docs.text:
• Darkened primary navbar color for better contrast and professional appearance
  • Fixed badge rendering in documentation home page
  • Converted markdown badge syntax to proper HTML with alignment attributes
  • Added CSS improvements for center-aligned content and badge spacing
  • Better visual hierarchy and spacing throughout documentation

docs.title: Internationalization
docs.text:
• Added "documentation" key to English and German locales
  • Added "viewAllReleases" key for release section button

docs.title: VOD Streams: Plex Integration
docs.text:
• Added new "VOD Streams" sidebar tab for monitoring Plex Media Server activities
  • Implemented Plex server configuration in Settings page with URL and token input
  • Added validation for Plex server connection before saving configuration
  • Real-time display of Plex downloads, streams, and transcode activities
  • Activity cards show progress bars, type badges (download/stream/transcode/pause), and titles
  • Monitor-style header with search functionality, LIVE indicator, and refresh button
  • Auto-refresh every 10 seconds for real-time activity updates
  • Three stat cards: Total activities, Online (downloads), Problem (errors)
  • Pagination support (10 items per page) for large activity lists
  • "Not configured" state with direct link to Settings when Plex is not set up
  • Bilingual support (English/German) for all UI elements

docs.title: Plex Backend: Comprehensive API
docs.text:
• Created /api/plex/config endpoints (GET/POST) for Plex server configuration management
  • Added /api/plex/validate endpoint for testing Plex connection before saving
  • Implemented /api/plex/activities endpoint fetching from both /activities (downloads) and /status/sessions (streams)
  • Added /api/downloads alias endpoint for compatibility
  • JSON file storage for Plex configuration at backend/data/plex_config.json
  • Debug endpoint /api/plex/debug/raw-activities for troubleshooting
  • Proper error handling and logging for all Plex operations

docs.title: Traffic Monitoring: Dashboard Integration
docs.text:
• Added traffic data display to Dashboard service cards
  • Shows upload/download speeds with color-coded icons (blue for upload, green for download)
  • Auto-refresh traffic data every 30 seconds
  • Traffic only displays when bandwidth > 0 for cleaner UI
  • Maintains separate layouts for Dashboard (inline cards) and Services page (ServiceCard component)

docs.title: Search Functionality: VOD Streams
docs.text:
• Implemented real-time search filtering for VOD activities
  • Search by title, subtitle, or activity type
  • Auto-reset to page 1 when search query changes
  • Clear search button when no results found
  • Different empty state messages for no activities vs. no search results

docs.title: Settings Page: Plex Configuration
docs.text:
• Added Plex Server Settings section below Authentication settings
  • Server URL and token input fields with validation
  • Visual feedback: green button for validated connection, red for failed
  • Loading spinner during validation process
  • Help text for finding Plex token
  • Theme-compatible button styling (smaller size, proper colors)

docs.title: Timezone: Configuration Bug
docs.text:
• Fixed timezone always showing UTC in About page
  • Removed conflicting @property timezone that was checking for TZ environment variable
  • Now correctly reads TIMEZONE from .env file (e.g., Europe/Berlin)
  • Backend properly returns configured timezone via /api/config endpoint
  • Frontend dateUtils correctly fetches and caches timezone for all date formatting

docs.title: Settings: Duplicate Authentication Section
docs.text:
• Removed duplicate Authentication Settings section that appeared after Plex settings
  • Proper order: Authentication → Plex → Language → Theme

docs.title: Plex Settings: Button Sizing
docs.text:
• Changed buttons from flex-1 (full width) to fixed width with px-6 padding
  • Reduced button height (py-2 instead of py-3) and font size (text-sm)
  • Smaller icons (16px instead of 20px, h-4 w-4 spinner)

docs.title: dateUtils: Improved Timezone Fetching
docs.text:
• Added caching mechanism to prevent multiple simultaneous timezone fetches
  • Console logging of loaded timezone for debugging
  • Proper async handling with promise reuse during concurrent requests

docs.title: Service Layer: Plex Abstraction
docs.text:
• Created frontend/src/services/plexService.js with clean API methods
  • Methods: testPlexConnection, getPlexConfig, savePlexConfig, fetchPlexActivities
  • Normalized data structure from different Plex endpoints
  • Proper error handling and user-friendly error messages

docs.title: Translations: Comprehensive Coverage
docs.text:
• Added vodStreams section to en.json and de.json
  • Added plex section with server settings, validation, and status messages
  • All UI elements fully translated in English and German

docs.title: Dependencies: Pydantic Settings
docs.text:
• Added pydantic-settings package for proper configuration management
  • Required for Pydantic v2 BaseSettings functionality

docs.title: Service Types: Added Server Type
docs.text:
• Added "Server" as a new service type option in Add/Edit Service modal
  • Server type available for traffic monitoring without health checks
  • Added translations for server type in English and German

docs.title: UI: Logo Integration
docs.text:
• Added Komandorr logo to sidebar, loading screen, and README
  • Integrated favicon.png for browser tabs
  • Sidebar logo displays at 48px height with auto-width
  • Loading screen logo displays at 64px height
  • README logo displays centered at 400px width

docs.title: UI: Refresh Button Improvements
docs.text:
• Added smooth spin animation to all refresh buttons
  • Renamed "Check Now" buttons to "Refresh" across all pages
  • Added 500ms transition duration for smooth rotation
  • Implemented disabled state during refresh operations

For the complete changelog history, visit the main CHANGELOG.md file.

docs.text: Komandorr provides a comprehensive RESTful API built with FastAPI, offering complete programmatic access to all features.

Local Development:

docs.title: Access Swagger UI
docs.text:
Visit the /docs endpoint:

http://localhost:8000/docs

Features:

  • Dark Theme: Matches Komandorr's design
  • Try It Out: Test endpoints directly in browser

docs.text:
Download the raw OpenAPI JSON:

http://localhost:8000/openapi.json

Use this with:

  • Postman
  • Insomnia
  • API clients and code generators

docs.title: Basic Auth (Optional)
docs.text:
When ENABLE_AUTH=true, all endpoints require Basic Authentication:

GET /api/services
Authorization: Basic base64(username:password)

Example with curl:

curl -u admin:password http://localhost:8000/api/services

Example with JavaScript:

const headers = {
  Authorization: "Basic " + btoa("admin:password"),
};

fetch("http://localhost:8000/api/services", { headers })
  .then((res) => res.json())
  .then((data) => console.log(data));

docs.title: No Authentication
docs.text: When ENABLE_AUTH=false, all endpoints are publicly accessible.

docs.title: Success Response
docs.text:
{
  "data": { ... },
  "status": "success"
}

or

{
  "services": [ ... ]
}

docs.title: Error Response
docs.text:
{
  "detail": "Error message here"
}

HTTP Status Codes:

Code Meaning 200 Success 201 Created 400 Bad Request 401 Unauthorized 404 Not Found 422 Validation Error 500 Server Error

docs.title: CORS
docs.text:
CORS is configured via the CORS_ORIGINS environment variable.

Default origins:

CORS_ORIGINS=http://localhost:3000,http://localhost:5173,http://localhost:8000

Custom origins:

CORS_ORIGINS=https://yourdomain.com,https://app.yourdomain.com

docs.title: Versioning
docs.text:
The API version is included in responses:

{
  "version": "1.4.0",
  "latest_version": "1.4.0",
  "update_available": false

Current API version: v1.4.0

No breaking changes are planned. Future versions will maintain backward compatibility.

docs.title: Client Libraries
docs.text:
Currently, official client libraries are not available. However, you can:

  1. Generate from OpenAPI: Use code generators like:

  2. openapi-generator

  3. swagger-codegen

  4. Use HTTP Libraries: Any standard HTTP client works:

  5. JavaScript: fetch, axios
  6. Python: requests, httpx
  7. Go: net/http
  8. PHP: guzzle

docs.title: List Services
docs.text:
curl http://localhost:8000/api/services

import requests

response = requests.get('http://localhost:8000/api/services')
services = response.json()['services']

docs.title: Create Service
docs.text:
curl -X POST http://localhost:8000/api/services \
  -H 'Content-Type: application/json' \
  -d '{
    "name": "My Website",
    "url": "https://example.com",
    "type": "website",
    "interval": 60
  }'

import requests

service = {
    "name": "My Website",
    "url": "https://example.com",
    "type": "website",
    "interval": 60
}

response = requests.post(
    'http://localhost:8000/api/services',
    json=service
)

docs.title: Get Plex Activities
docs.text:
curl http://localhost:8000/api/plex/activities

const activities = await fetch(
  "http://localhost:8000/api/plex/activities"
).then((res) => res.json());

console.log(activities);

docs.title: Error Handling
docs.text:
Always check status codes and handle errors:

const response = await fetch("/api/services");

if (!response.ok) {
  const error = await response.json();
  console.error("API Error:", error.detail);
  return;
}

const data = await response.json();

docs.title: Request Timeouts
docs.text:
Set appropriate timeouts:

import requests

try:
    response = requests.get(
        'http://localhost:8000/api/services',
        timeout=5
    )
except requests.Timeout:
    print('Request timed out')

docs.title: Retry Logic
docs.text:
Implement retries for transient failures:

from requests.adapters import HTTPAdapter
from requests.packages.urllib3.util.retry import Retry

session = requests.Session()
retry = Retry(total=3, backoff_factor=0.3)
adapter = HTTPAdapter(max_retries=retry)
session.mount('http://', adapter)

response = session.get('http://localhost:8000/api/services')

}

# Download agent
wget https://raw.githubusercontent.com/cyb3rgh05t/komandorr/main/traffic/traffic_agent.py

pip install psutil requests

docs.title: Configuration

docs.title: Manual

docs.title: Dashboard
docs.text: The Dashboard is the main landing page of Komandorr, providing an at-a-glance view of all your monitored services.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: The Dashboard displays all your services in a clean, organized layout with real-time status updates, traffic information, and service grouping capabilities.

docs.title: Service Cards
docs.text:
Each service is displayed in a card showing:

  • Service Name: The display name of your service
  • Status Indicator: Color-coded status (Online, Offline, Error)
  • Service Type: Icon and label (Website, App, Panel, Server)
  • Description: Optional service description
  • Response Time: Last measured response time in milliseconds
  • Last Check: Time since last health check
  • Traffic Data: Upload/download speeds (if configured)

docs.title: Service Groups
docs.text:
Organize services into logical groups:

  • Tabbed Interface: Multiple groups displayed as tabs
  • Group Counts: Badge showing number of services per group
  • Ungrouped Services: Services without a group appear in "All Services"

docs.title: Status Colors
docs.text:
Services are color-coded by status:

Status Color Meaning Online Green Service responding normally Offline Red Service not responding Error Yellow Service error or timeout

docs.title: Traffic Integration
docs.text:
When traffic monitoring is configured:

  • Upload Speed: Blue upward arrow with MB/s
  • Download Speed: Green downward arrow with MB/s
  • Real-time Updates: Refreshes every 30 seconds
  • Conditional Display: Only shows when bandwidth > 0

docs.title: Viewing Services
docs.text:
1. Navigate to Dashboard from the sidebar
  2. View all services at once or switch between groups
  3. Click on a service card to see more details

docs.title: Service Actions
docs.text:
Each service card provides quick actions:

  • Open URL: Click the service name to open in new tab
  • View Details: Click card for full service information
  • Quick Status: Glance at color-coded status

docs.title: Organizing with Groups
docs.text:
Create groups to organize services:

  1. Go to Services page
  2. Add or edit a service
  3. Enter a group name (e.g., "Production", "Development", "Media")
  4. Services with the same group name appear together

Examples of groups:

  • Production - Live production services
  • Development - Development environment
  • Media - Plex, Jellyfin, Emby servers
  • Infrastructure - DNS, VPN, Monitoring tools

docs.title: Auto-Refresh
docs.text:
The Dashboard automatically updates service status:

  • Check Interval: Configurable per service (default: 60 seconds)
  • Visual Updates: Status changes reflected in real-time
  • Traffic Refresh: Every 30 seconds

docs.title: Service Naming
docs.text:
Use clear, descriptive names:

  • Good: Plex Media Server
  • Good: Website - Production
  • Good: VPN Gateway
  • Bad: srv1
  • Bad: test

docs.title: Grouping Strategy
docs.text:
Organize by:

  • Environment: Production, Staging, Development
  • Function: Media, Infrastructure, Applications
  • Location: US-East, EU-West, Asia-Pacific
  • Priority: Critical, Important, Monitoring

docs.title: Check Intervals
docs.text:
Set appropriate intervals:

  • Critical Services: 30-60 seconds
  • Standard Services: 60-120 seconds
  • Low Priority: 300-900 seconds (5-15 minutes)

Performance

Too many services with short intervals can impact performance. Balance monitoring needs with system resources.

docs.title: Themes
docs.text:
Change the Dashboard appearance:

  1. Click your username → Theme
  2. Choose from: Dark, Plex, Jellyfin, Emby, etc.
  3. Theme applies instantly

docs.title: Language
docs.text:
Switch language:

  1. Click your username → Language
  2. Select English or Deutsch (German)

docs.title: Keyboard Shortcuts
docs.text: Shortcut Action Tab Navigate between service cards Enter Open selected service URL Ctrl/Cmd + K Focus search (if available)

docs.title: Services Not Updating
docs.text:
1. Check backend is running: http://localhost:8000/api/health
  2. Verify service URL is correct
  3. Check logs: backend/logs/app.log

docs.title: Traffic Not Showing
docs.text:
1. Ensure traffic agent is running on the server
  2. Verify service ID matches in agent configuration
  3. Check network connectivity between agent and Komandorr

docs.title: Groups Not Appearing
docs.text:
1. Ensure multiple services have the same group name
  2. Check for typos in group names
  3. Refresh the page

docs.title: VOD Streams (Plex Integration)
docs.text: Monitor your Plex Media Server activities in real-time with the VOD Streams feature.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
The VOD Streams page provides live monitoring of Plex Media Server activities, including:

  • Downloads and sync operations
  • Active streams
  • Transcoding sessions
  • Media processing status

docs.title: Real-time Activity Monitoring
docs.text:
Track all Plex server activities:

  • Downloads: Media being downloaded or synced
  • Streams: Active playback sessions
  • Transcoding: Media being transcoded
  • Paused: Temporarily paused operations

docs.title: Activity Information
docs.text:
Each activity shows:

  • Title & Subtitle: Media name and episode/season info
  • Progress Bar: Visual progress indicator (0-100%)
  • Type Badge: Activity type (download, stream, transcode, pause)
  • Status: Current state of the operation

docs.title: Search & Filter
docs.text:
Quickly find activities:

  • Real-time Search: Filter as you type
  • Search Fields: Title, subtitle, activity type
  • Auto-reset: Returns to page 1 on new search

docs.title: Pagination
docs.text:
Handle large activity lists:

  • 10 Items Per Page: Clean, organized display
  • Page Navigation: Previous/Next buttons
  • Page Counter: Current page and total pages

docs.title: Statistics
docs.text:
Three summary cards show:

  • Total Activities: All current operations
  • Online: Active downloads and syncs
  • Problem: Failed or errored activities

docs.title: Auto-Refresh
docs.text:
Stay up-to-date automatically:

  • 10-Second Refresh: Live updates every 10 seconds
  • LIVE Indicator: Shows real-time status
  • Manual Refresh: Force refresh with button

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
• Plex Media Server running and accessible
  • Plex token for authentication

docs.title: Configuration
docs.text:
1. Navigate to Settings
  2. Scroll to Plex Server Settings
  3. Enter your Plex server URL: 
    http://your-plex-server:32400
  4. Enter your Plex token (How to find)
  5. Click Test Connection
  6. If successful (green button), click Save Configuration

docs.title: Finding Your Plex Token
docs.text:
1. Log into Plex Web App
  2. Play any media item
  3. Click the info icon (ⓘ)
  4. Click "View XML"
  5. Look for X-Plex-Token in the URL

Or follow the official guide.

docs.title: Viewing Activities
docs.text:
1. Click VOD Streams in the sidebar
  2. See all current Plex activities
  3. Use search to filter specific items

docs.title: Activity Types
docs.text:
Different badge colors indicate activity types:

Type Badge Color Description Download Blue Media being downloaded/synced Stream Green Active streaming session Transcode Orange Media being transcoded Pause Gray Paused operation

docs.title: Progress Tracking
docs.text:
Progress bars show completion:

  • 0%: Just started
  • 50%: Halfway complete
  • 100%: Finished

docs.title: Search Examples
docs.text:
Search for:

  • Movie name: Avatar
  • TV show: Breaking Bad
  • Season: S01
  • Episode: E05
  • Activity type: download

docs.title: Download Activities
docs.text:
Downloads from /activities endpoint:

{
  "title": "Movie Title",
  "subtitle": "2023",
  "progress": 45,
  "type": "download"
}

Indicates:

  • User downloading media for offline viewing
  • Plex sync operation in progress
  • Mobile or desktop app sync

docs.title: Stream Activities
docs.text:
Live streams from /status/sessions endpoint:

{
  "title": "TV Show",
  "subtitle": "S01E01 - Episode Name",
  "progress": 23,
  "type": "stream"
}

Indicates:

  • Active playback session
  • User watching content
  • Real-time streaming

docs.title: Transcode Operations
docs.text:
Media being converted:

{
  "title": "4K Movie",
  "subtitle": "Transcoding to 1080p",
  "progress": 67,
  "type": "transcode"
}

Indicates:

  • Format conversion in progress
  • Quality adjustment for client
  • Codec compatibility processing

docs.title: No Activities Showing
docs.text:
Possible causes:

  1. No Active Operations: No current downloads or streams
  2. Connection Issue: Plex server not reachable
  3. Wrong Token: Invalid authentication token
  4. URL Error: Incorrect server URL

Solutions:

  1. Verify Plex is running: http://your-plex-server:32400/web
  2. Test connection in Settings
  3. Check token is correct
  4. Ensure URL includes port (:32400)

docs.title: "Not Configured" Message
docs.text:
Plex settings missing:

  1. Go to Settings
  2. Configure Plex Server Settings
  3. Save configuration
  4. Return to VOD Streams page

docs.title: Activities Not Updating
docs.text:
1. Check auto-refresh is enabled (LIVE indicator)
  2. Manually click refresh button
  3. Check browser console for errors
  4. Verify backend is running

docs.title: Connection Failed
docs.text:
Error: Failed to connect to Plex server

Check:

  • Server URL is correct
  • Plex server is running
  • Network connectivity
  • Firewall rules
  • Port 32400 is accessible

docs.title: API Endpoints
docs.text: VOD Streams uses these backend endpoints:

docs.title: Get Configuration
docs.text:
GET /api/plex/config

Returns current Plex configuration.

docs.title: Save Configuration
docs.text:
POST /api/plex/config
Content-Type: application/json

{
  "server_url": "http://plex:32400",
  "token": "your-token"
}

docs.title: Validate Connection
docs.text:
POST /api/plex/validate
Content-Type: application/json

{
  "server_url": "http://plex:32400",
  "token": "your-token"
}

docs.title: Get Activities
docs.text:
GET /api/plex/activities

Returns combined activities from both downloads and streams.

docs.title: Network Configuration
docs.text:
• Use local network address for faster responses
  • Avoid remote connections if possible
  • Consider reverse proxy for HTTPS

docs.title: Token Security
docs.text:
• Keep token private
  • Don't commit to version control
  • Rotate tokens periodically
  • Use environment variables in production

docs.title: Performance
docs.text:
• Auto-refresh is optimized (10s interval)
  • Pagination handles large lists efficiently
  • Search is client-side (instant results)

docs.title: Limitations
docs.text:
• Shows only current/active operations
  • No historical data
  • Limited to Plex's API capabilities
  • Requires valid Plex Pass for some features

docs.title: Future Enhancements
docs.text:
Planned improvements:

  • Activity history and logs
  • Download speed tracking
  • Client device information
  • Cancel/pause operations
  • Notifications for new downloads
  • Export activity data

docs.title: Configuration
docs.text: Complete configuration guide for Komandorr.

docs.title: Environment Variables
docs.text:
Komandorr is configured using environment variables. You can set these in:

  • .env file in the project root
  • docker-compose.yml environment section
  • System environment variables

docs.title: ENABLE_AUTH
docs.text:
Enable or disable authentication.

ENABLE_AUTH=false  # Default: false

Values:

  • true: Enable basic authentication
  • false: Disable authentication (open access)

docs.title: TIMEZONE
docs.text:
Set the application timezone for logs and timestamps.

TIMEZONE=Europe/Berlin  # Default: UTC

Examples:

  • America/New_York
  • Asia/Tokyo
  • Europe/London

List of timezones

docs.title: DEBUG
docs.text:
Enable debug mode for detailed logging.

DEBUG=false  # Default: false

Values:

  • true: Enable debug logging
  • false: Standard logging only

docs.title: Authentication Settings
docs.text: When ENABLE_AUTH=true, configure credentials:

docs.title: AUTH_USERNAME
docs.text:
Username for authentication.

AUTH_USERNAME=admin  # Default: admin

docs.title: AUTH_PASSWORD
docs.text:
Password for authentication.

AUTH_PASSWORD=your-secure-password  # Default: admin

Security

Change the default password before exposing Komandorr to the internet!

docs.title: CORS Settings
docs.text: Configure allowed origins for API access.

docs.title: CORS_ORIGINS
docs.text:
Comma-separated list of allowed origins.

CORS_ORIGINS=http://localhost:3000,https://yourdomain.com

Default:

CORS_ORIGINS=http://localhost:3000,http://localhost:5173,http://localhost:8000

docs.title: HOST
docs.text:
Backend server host address.

HOST=0.0.0.0  # Default: 0.0.0.0

docs.title: PORT
docs.text:
Backend server port.

PORT=8000  # Default: 8000

docs.title: RELOAD
docs.text:
Enable auto-reload for development.

RELOAD=false  # Default: false

Note

Set RELOAD=true only in development. Disable in production.

docs.title: Services Configuration
docs.text:
Services are stored in backend/data/services.json:

{
  "services": [
    {
      "id": "uuid-here",
      "name": "My Website",
      "url": "https://example.com",
      "type": "website",
      "group": "Production",
      "interval": 60,
      "description": "Main website",
      "icon": "globe",
      "enabled": true,
      "status": "online",
      "last_check": "2025-01-08T10:30:00Z",
      "response_time": 150
    }
  ]
}

Fields:

  • id: Unique identifier (UUID)
  • name: Service display name
  • url: Service endpoint URL
  • type: Service type (website, app, panel, server)
  • group: Optional group name
  • interval: Check interval in seconds
  • description: Service description
  • icon: Icon name (from Lucide icons)
  • enabled: Enable/disable monitoring
  • status: Current status (online, offline, error)
  • last_check: Last check timestamp
  • response_time: Response time in milliseconds

docs.title: Plex Configuration
docs.text:
Plex settings are stored in backend/data/plex_config.json:

{
  "server_url": "http://plex-server:32400",
  "token": "your-plex-token-here"
}

Configuration via UI:

  1. Go to Settings → Plex Server Settings
  2. Enter server URL and token
  3. Click Test Connection
  4. Click Save Configuration

Finding your Plex token:

  • Official Guide

docs.title: Traffic Configuration
docs.text:
Traffic agents are configured per service using the agent script:

python traffic_agent.py --setup

Required information:

  • Backend URL: http://komandorr-server:8000
  • Service ID: Copy from service card in Komandorr UI

docs.title: Docker Compose Configuration
docs.text:
Example docker-compose.yml:

version: "3.8"

services:
  komandorr:
    image: ghcr.io/cyb3rgh05t/komandorr:latest
    container_name: komandorr
    ports:
      - "3000:80" # Frontend
      - "8000:8000" # Backend
    volumes:
      - ./backend/data:/app/backend/data
      - ./backend/logs:/app/backend/logs
    environment:
      # Core Settings
      ENABLE_AUTH: "false"
      TIMEZONE: "Europe/Berlin"
      DEBUG: "false"

      # Authentication (if ENABLE_AUTH=true)
      AUTH_USERNAME: "admin"
      AUTH_PASSWORD: "your-secure-password"

      # CORS
      CORS_ORIGINS: "http://localhost:3000"

      # Backend
      HOST: "0.0.0.0"
      PORT: "8000"
      RELOAD: "false"
    restart: unless-stopped

docs.title: Frontend Configuration
docs.text:
Frontend API endpoint is configured in frontend/vite.config.js:

export default defineConfig({
  server: {
    proxy: {
      "/api": {
        target: "http://localhost:8000",
        changeOrigin: true,
      },
    },
  },
});

docs.title: Check Intervals
docs.text:
Configure how often services are checked:

Interval Use Case 30s Critical services requiring immediate alerts 60s Standard monitoring (recommended) 300s (5m) Low-priority services 900s (15m) Infrequent checks

docs.title: Auto-Refresh Intervals
docs.text: Feature Refresh Rate Configurable VOD Streams 10 seconds In code only Traffic Data 30 seconds In code only Service Status 60 seconds Via check interval

docs.title: Custom Themes
docs.text:
Themes are defined in frontend/src/index.css. To add a custom theme:

[data-theme="custom"] {
  --color-primary: #your-color;
  --color-background: #your-bg;
  /* ... more variables ... */
}

Then add to theme dropdown in ThemeDropdown.jsx.

docs.title: Custom Icons
docs.text:
Icons are from Lucide React. To add new icons:

  1. Import in component: import { YourIcon } from 'lucide-react'
  2. Use: <YourIcon className="h-5 w-5" />

docs.title: Logging Configuration
docs.text:
Logging is configured in backend/app/utils/logger.py:

# Log levels
logging.DEBUG    # Detailed debug information
logging.INFO     # General information (default)
logging.WARNING  # Warning messages
logging.ERROR    # Error messages
logging.CRITICAL # Critical errors

Set DEBUG=true to enable DEBUG level logging.

docs.title: Production Deployment
docs.text:
# Use environment file
ENABLE_AUTH=true
AUTH_PASSWORD=strong-random-password-here
DEBUG=false
RELOAD=false
CORS_ORIGINS=https://yourdomain.com

# Use volumes for persistence
volumes:
  - ./data:/app/backend/data
  - ./logs:/app/backend/logs

# Use restart policy
restart: unless-stopped

docs.title: Security
docs.text:
1. Enable Authentication: Set ENABLE_AUTH=true
  2. Strong Passwords: Use complex passwords
  3. HTTPS: Use reverse proxy with SSL
  4. Restrict CORS: Only allow necessary origins
  5. Regular Updates: Keep Komandorr updated

docs.title: Performance
docs.text:
1. Check Intervals: Don't check too frequently
  2. Service Count: Monitor 100+ services efficiently
  3. Traffic Agents: Use one agent per server
  4. Log Rotation: Implement log rotation

docs.title: Installation
docs.text: This guide will help you install Komandorr using different methods.

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
Before installing Komandorr, ensure you have one of the following:

=== "Docker (Recommended)" - Docker Engine 20.10+ - Docker Compose 2.0+

=== "Manual Installation" - Python 3.9+ - Node.js 18+ - npm or yarn

docs.title: Docker Compose (Recommended)
docs.text:
The easiest way to run Komandorr is using Docker Compose:

# Clone the repository
git clone https://github.com/cyb3rgh05t/komandorr.git
cd komandorr

# Start the services
docker-compose up -d

The application will be available at:

  • Frontend: http://localhost:3000
  • Backend API: http://localhost:8000
  • API Documentation: http://localhost:8000/docs

docs.title: Docker Run
docs.text:
If you prefer using Docker without Compose:

# Pull the image
docker pull ghcr.io/cyb3rgh05t/komandorr:latest

# Run the container
docker run -d \
  --name komandorr \
  -p 3000:80 \
  -p 8000:8000 \
  -v $(pwd)/backend/data:/app/backend/data \
  -v $(pwd)/backend/logs:/app/backend/logs \
  -e ENABLE_AUTH=false \
  -e TIMEZONE=Europe/Berlin \
  ghcr.io/cyb3rgh05t/komandorr:latest

docs.title: Manual Installation
docs.text: For development or custom setups:

docs.title: Backend Setup
docs.text:
# Navigate to backend directory
cd backend

# Create virtual environment
python -m venv venv

# Activate virtual environment
# On Windows:
venv\Scripts\activate
# On Linux/Mac:
source venv/bin/activate

# Install dependencies
pip install -r requirements.txt

# Run the backend
python run.py

The backend API will start on http://localhost:8000.

docs.title: Frontend Setup
docs.text:
# Navigate to frontend directory
cd frontend

# Install dependencies
npm install

# Start development server
npm run dev

The frontend will start on http://localhost:5173 (Vite default).

For production build:

npm run build
npm run preview

docs.title: Verify Installation
docs.text:
After installation, verify everything is working:

  1. Check Frontend: Open http://localhost:3000 in your browser
  2. Check Backend: Visit http://localhost:8000/api/health
  3. Check API Docs: Navigate to http://localhost:8000/docs

You should see:

  • Frontend loads with the dashboard
  • Backend health check returns {"status": "healthy"}
  • Swagger UI documentation displays

docs.title: Post-Installation
docs.text:
After successful installation:

  1. Configure Services: Add your first service to monitor
  2. Set Up Plex (optional): Configure Plex server for VOD monitoring
  3. Configure Traffic (optional): Set up traffic monitoring agent
  4. Enable Authentication (optional): Secure your dashboard

Configuration Guide

docs.title: Port Already in Use
docs.text:
If ports 3000 or 8000 are already in use, modify the docker-compose.yml:

services:
  frontend:
    ports:
      - "3001:80" # Change 3000 to 3001
  backend:
    ports:
      - "8001:8000" # Change 8000 to 8001

docs.title: Permission Issues
docs.text:
If you encounter permission issues with Docker volumes:

# Create directories with proper permissions
mkdir -p backend/data backend/logs
chmod 755 backend/data backend/logs

docs.title: Python Version Issues
docs.text:
Komandorr requires Python 3.9+. Check your version:

python --version

If needed, use a specific Python version:

python3.9 -m venv venv

docs.text:
Using Docker Compose (recommended):

git clone https://github.com/cyb3rgh05t/komandorr.git
cd komandorr
docker-compose up -d

Wait for the containers to start, then open http://localhost:3000.

docs.title: Step 2: Add Your First Service
docs.text:
1. Click the Services tab in the sidebar
  2. Click the Add Service button (➕)
  3. Fill in the service details:
Name: My Website
URL: https://example.com
Type: Website
Group: Production (optional)
Check Interval: 60 seconds
Description: My main website
  1. Click Add Service

Your service will appear on the dashboard with its current status!

docs.title: Change Theme
docs.text:
1. Click your username in the top-right corner
  2. Select Theme
  3. Choose from: Dark, Plex, Jellyfin, Emby, and more

docs.title: Change Language
docs.text:
1. Click your username in the top-right corner
  2. Select Language
  3. Choose: English or Deutsch (German)

docs.title: Step 4: Configure Plex (Optional)
docs.text:
Monitor your Plex Media Server activities:

  1. Go to Settings
  2. Scroll to Plex Server Settings
  3. Enter your Plex server URL: http://your-plex-server:32400
  4. Add your Plex token
  5. Click Test Connection
  6. Click Save Configuration

Now visit the VOD Streams tab to see live Plex activities!

docs.title: Step 5: Set Up Traffic Monitoring (Optional)
docs.text: Monitor bandwidth usage per service:

docs.title: Install Traffic Agent
docs.text:
On your server (where services run):

# Download the agent
wget https://raw.githubusercontent.com/cyb3rgh05t/komandorr/main/traffic/traffic_agent.py

# Install dependencies
pip install psutil requests

# Configure the agent
python traffic_agent.py --setup

Provide:

  • Komandorr backend URL: http://your-komandorr-server:8000
  • Service ID: (copy from service card in Komandorr)

docs.title: Start the Agent
docs.text:
# Run manually (for testing)
python traffic_agent.py

# Or install as systemd service
sudo python traffic_agent.py --install-service

Traffic data will appear on your Dashboard service cards!

docs.title: View Service Monitoring
docs.text:
Click the Monitor tab to see:

  • All services with status
  • Response times
  • Last check timestamps
  • Error messages (if any)

docs.title: Check API Documentation
docs.text: Visit http://localhost:8000/docs to explore the API with Swagger UI.

docs.title: View Application Logs
docs.text:
# Docker
docker-compose logs -f backend

# Manual installation
tail -f backend/logs/app.log

docs.title: Development Guide
docs.text: Set up Komandorr for local development.

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
• Python 3.9+
  • Node.js 18+
  • Git

docs.title: Backend Setup
docs.text:
cd backend
python -m venv venv

# Windows
venv\Scripts\activate

# Linux/Mac
source venv/bin/activate

pip install -r requirements.txt
python run.py

Backend runs on http://localhost:8000

docs.title: Frontend Setup
docs.text:
cd frontend
npm install
npm run dev

Frontend runs on http://localhost:5173

docs.title: Development Workflow
docs.text:
1. Make changes to code
  2. Test locally
  3. Run tests (if available)
  4. Commit with descriptive message
  5. Push to GitHub

docs.title: Troubleshooting
docs.text: Common issues and solutions.

docs.title: Services Not Updating
docs.text:
Issue: Services show old status or don't update.

Solutions:

  • Check backend is running: http://localhost:8000/api/health
  • Verify service URL is accessible
  • Check logs: backend/logs/app.log
  • Verify check interval settings

docs.title: Authentication Issues
docs.text:
Issue: Can't login or auth not working.

Solutions:

  • Verify ENABLE_AUTH=true in environment
  • Check username/password are correct
  • Clear browser cache and cookies
  • Check backend logs for auth errors

docs.title: Plex Connection Failed
docs.text:
Issue: Can't connect to Plex server.

Solutions:

  • Verify Plex server is running
  • Check server URL is correct (include :32400)
  • Ensure token is valid
  • Test URL in browser: http://your-plex:32400/web
  • Check firewall rules

docs.title: Traffic Not Showing
docs.text:
Issue: Traffic data not appearing on dashboard.

Solutions:

  • Ensure traffic agent is running on server
  • Verify service ID matches in agent config
  • Check network connectivity
  • Review agent logs
  • Confirm backend can receive POST requests

docs.title: Docker Issues
docs.text:
Issue: Container won't start or crashes.

Solutions:

  • Check logs: docker-compose logs -f
  • Verify ports aren't already in use
  • Check volume permissions
  • Ensure environment variables are set
  • Try rebuilding: docker-compose up -d --build

docs.title: Performance Issues
docs.text:
Issue: Slow loading or high resource usage.

Solutions:

  • Increase check intervals for services
  • Reduce number of concurrent checks
  • Check system resources (CPU, RAM)
  • Review logs for errors
  • Consider dedicated server for larger deployments

docs.title: Frontend Issues
docs.text:
Issue: UI not loading or blank page.

Solutions:

  • Hard refresh: Ctrl+Shift+R (Cmd+Shift+R on Mac)
  • Clear browser cache
  • Check browser console for errors
  • Verify backend is accessible
  • Check CORS settings
